stem: The nurse is assessing a 9-month-old infant during a routine well-child visit. Based on the provided information, match each behavior to the expected age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
14:00 SBAR for Patient: Baby Michael, Age: 9 months.
Situation: Baby Michael is here for a routine 9-month well-child check-up. Parents have a few questions about feeding and sleeping habits.
Background: Michael was born full-term with no complications. He has been meeting most developmental milestones, according to the parents. He received all recommended vaccinations at his 6-month appointment. Parents report Michael is generally healthy, with occasional mild colds.
Assessment: On examination, Michael is alert, active, and appears to be developing normally. He sits unsupported and is starting to crawl. He babbles frequently, using sounds like 'mama' and 'dada' without specific intent. He shows interest in toys and objects around him, attempting to reach for them. He pulls himself to stand while holding onto furniture. Parents report he sleeps through the night most nights, with occasional wake-ups.
Recommendation: Continue to monitor Michael’s development. Discuss feeding strategies, emphasizing iron-rich foods. Reinforce the importance of upcoming vaccinations. Address parental concerns regarding sleep patterns and offer guidance. Schedule next appointment for 12-month check-up.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab results available for this visit.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert, active, in no acute distress.
HEENT: Head normocephalic, fontanelles open but not bulging. Eyes clear, PERRL. Ears normal, TMs intact. Nose clear, no discharge. Mouth with two bottom incisors present.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present.
Neurological: Moves all extremities, demonstrates age-appropriate reflexes. Sits unsupported. Pulls to stand holding furniture.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1. Administer routine vaccinations per schedule.
2. Provide parental education on nutrition, safety, and developmental milestones.
3. Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered during this visit.

rows.text: Pulls to stand while holding furniture
Transfers objects from one hand to the other
Crawls with abdomen off the floor

rationale.correct: All listed behaviors are generally expected around the 9-month mark. Pulling to stand, transferring objects, nonspecific 'mama'/'dada' sounds, sitting unsupported, and crawling with abdomen off the floor are all milestones typically achieved by infants around this age.
rationale.incorrect: Selecting 6 months or 12 months indicates a misunderstanding of the typical age range for these developmental milestones.

answerBreakdown.text: Pulls to stand while holding furniture
answerBreakdown.rationale: Infants typically begin pulling themselves up to a standing position while holding onto furniture around 9 months of age. This indicates developing gross motor skills and leg strength.

answerBreakdown.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other
answerBreakdown.rationale: The ability to transfer objects from one hand to the other usually develops around 9 months. This demonstrates improved hand-eye coordination and fine motor skills.
Babbling 'mama' and 'dada' without specific intent is a common milestone around 9 months. This is a precursor to using these words with specific meaning.
Most infants can sit unsupported by 9 months. This shows good trunk control and balance.

answerBreakdown.text: Crawls with abdomen off the floor
answerBreakdown.rationale: Crawling with the abdomen off the floor typically develops around 9 months. This indicates significant progress in gross motor skills and coordination.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones are ranges, not fixed dates. Variations are normal.
Assessments should be individualized and consider the child's overall development.
Parental input is crucial in assessing developmental progress.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming milestones are rigidly defined at specific ages.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that milestones are ranges and individual variations are common. Focus on the most likely age range based on the described behavior.

mnemonic.title: SIT-C-P
mnemonic.expansion: Sitting unsupported, Inter-hand transfer, Nonspecific Talk, Crawling, Pulling to stand - all occur around 9 months.
